p: First, the numbers in this figure do not make sense. According to the presented data, seven (synonymous) substitutions have a derived frequency of >50 per cent, and four of these mutations have derived frequencies >95 per cent in the population. A cursory glance at the tree in Fig. 2 shows that this cannot be true. ‘ Derived’ in this context should mean a sequence change away from the genome of the last common ancestor of the outbreak. For four mutations to have derived frequencies >95 per cent, there would need to be a small number of samples which branch as a sister lineage to the rest of the outbreak tree. However, this is not the case.
